messages.message: This doesn’t seem a refiner specific problem but rather a problem with our underlying infrastructure and the observability of it no? Like, what insight do we have into task execution queues, etc
If the execution is unstable, that doesn’t seem like a code issue but an infra issue. If it is *always* slow, then we probably need to optimize the performance of the refiner execution code.

I think the problem is, right now, when things are slow, we don’t know if it’s the infra or a particular user’s code. Though I guess you can take a glance at the code and try to guess if it would be slow or not
@Anant you should take a look at the product roadmap because I believe observability and load testing were specifically prioritized as lowest priority, either P2 or lower than P2.

@lydia - agreed - this can be a combination of both underlying infra and the users of the infra (ex: flow, refiner, udf, service code etc). This is one of the most important priorities for observability team to [1] help surface the data to, [2] identify the bottlenecks in the system using #1.

My previous comment did not have enough context. To clarify if we can achieve #1 and #2 the natural next step will be to run a set of periodic tests that benchmark performance, identify bottlenecks, and the cause of them.
